chapters.title: GitTip profile of the week
chapters.header: I stopped including GitTip links as they seemed to have only minimal impact, but if you think you'd want to tip the editors of the newsletter you can do it here.

entries.title: How should conference speakers be compensated?
entries.text: brian d foy explains how the Master Classes he started to run at YAPC::Chicago in 2006 helped financing some of the speakers. IMHO, as I also wrote already this is a win-win and such trainig classes can even help sponsoring other parts of the conference.

entries.title: Mojolicious â€“ Perl real-time web framework
entries.text: A long thread of discussion on HackerNews that of course diverges to the discussion of OOP in Perl and sigils and whatnot.

entries.title: Perl as a career option
entries.text: Andrew Solomon has been interviewed by Linux Career covering quite a few topic from 'Modern Perl' via web development to 'how to get started with Perl'.

entries.title: Rescue legacy code with modulinos
entries.text: Modulino is a Perl module that can be also used as a script. brian d foy explains how this feature can be used to convert scripts into modules and make it easier to start testing them.

entries.title: Parse Excel with ease using Perl
entries.text: David Farrell shows how to read Excel files using Spreadsheet::Read.

entries.title: Catalyst vs Dancer vs Mojolicious on Stack Overflow
entries.text: I checked the number of posts on Stack Overflow tagged with each one of those: Catalyst: 380, Mojolicious: 213, Dancer: 133. Does this mean anything?

entries.title: Don't be afraid to rename your module / dist
entries.text: Neil Bowers explains module name choices and how to rename a module.

entries.title: Curating CPAN sometimes means really deleting stuff
entries.text: Philippe Bruhat (BooK) shows 3 cases when he decide a module should be totally removed from CPAN and uses his examples to encourage others too to remove obsolete modules.

entries.title: Fix a bug on CPAN Day
entries.text: It is Neil Bowers again (I really hope he will create a post linking to all of his CPAN-day related posts) showing how the number of bugs on RT are steadily growing (but not even looking at bugs reported elsewhere). More importantly he created a list of the to 20 distributions in terms of open RT tickets. There are some very important modules in that list! Go ahead, you can fix a bug or at least write a test case.

entries.title: Don't declare a dependency on Crypt::SSLeay (or IO::Socket::SSL either)
entries.text: Instead of that, if your code uses https then declare a dependency on LWP::Protocol::https.

entries.title: Fix your CPAN Testers failures on CPAN Day
entries.text: Another thing you can do to help CPAN and the Perl ecosystem.

entries.title: Maintaining Perl 5: Grant Report for Month 11
entries.text: The monthly report from Tony Cook. (The unofficial list of grants and reports is here.)

entries.title: Maintaining Perl 5: Grant Report for Month 12
GSoC Week 11: Improving Documentation for MetaCPAN.
entries.text: Talina Shrotriya keeps herself busy with MetaCPAN activity heading towards the "Web of Trust" that will hopefully vastly improve the search results on MetaCPAN.

entries.title: perlcc next steps
entries.text: Compiling Perl code to executable? Some crazy optimizations done by Reini Urban at cPanel.
